problem_data.question: Strip all but one electron off an aluminum atom \((Z=13, A=27)\) to form a hydrogen-like atom. Consider such a hydrogen-like atom. For the electron's ground state, calculate the effect of the finite size of the nucleus. Specifically, compute the difference in the ground state energy when the nucleus is considered as a point nucleus versus when the nucleus is considered as being of its physically realistic size (assuming the nucleus is a uniformly charged sphere). Express the result in electron volts.
problem_data.solution:
For a spherically symmetric distribution, the potential outside the sphere is clearly

\[ 
V_{1} = -\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}, \quad r > \rho, \quad \rho \text{ is the radius of the nucleus}
\]

Inside the nucleus, the force on the electron is

\[
F = Z e^{2}\left(\frac{r}{\rho}\right)^{3} \frac{1}{r^{2}} = \frac{Z e^{2} r}{\rho^{3}}
\]

Thus, the potential is

\[
V_{2} = \frac{Z e^{2}}{2 \rho^{3}} r^{2} + C, \quad C \text{ is an undetermined constant}
\]

The continuity of the potential at the surface of the nucleus gives

\[
\begin{aligned}
V_{1}(\rho) &= V_{2}(\rho) \\
C &= -\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{Z e^{2}}{\rho}
\end{aligned}
\]

therefore,

\[ 
V_{2}(r) = \frac{Z e^{2}}{2 \rho^{3}} r^{2} - \frac{3}{2} \frac{Z e^{2}}{\rho}, \quad r < \rho
\]

The Hamiltonian of the electron is

\[
H = \frac{P^{2}}{2m} + V_{0}(r) + H^{\prime}
\]

where

\[
\left\{
\begin{aligned}
& V_{0}(r) = -\frac{Z e^{2}}{r}, \quad \infty > r > 0 \\
& H^{\prime} = \begin{cases} 
0, & r > \rho \\
\frac{Z e^{2}}{2 \rho}\left[\left(\frac{r}{\rho}\right)^{2}+\frac{2 \rho}{r}-3\right], & r < \rho
\end{cases}
\end{aligned}\right.
\]

Therefore,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle 100| H^{\prime}|100\rangle &= \int_{0}^{\infty} r^{2} \, \mathrm{d} r \, R_{10}^{*}(r) R_{10}(r) \, H^{\prime}(r) \\
&= \int_{0}^{\rho} r^{2} \, \mathrm{d} r \, R_{10}^{2}(r) \frac{Z e^{2}}{2 \rho}\left[\left(\frac{r}{\rho}\right)^{2}+\frac{2 \rho}{r}-3\right] \\
&= \int_{0}^{\rho} \frac{Z^{4} e^{2}}{a^{3}} \, \mathrm{e}^{-2 Z r / a}\left(\frac{1}{r}-\frac{3}{2 \rho}+\frac{r^{2}}{2 \rho^{3}}\right) 4 r^{2} \, \mathrm{d} r
\end{aligned}
\]

where \(a=\frac{\hbar^{2}}{m e^{2}} = 5.3 \times 10^{-9} \, \mathrm{cm}\) is the Bohr radius. Since \(\rho = r_{0} A^{1 / 3}, r_{0} = 10^{-13} \, \mathrm{cm}\), and

\[
\frac{Z \rho}{a} = \frac{r_{0} A^{1 / 3} Z}{a} \approx 0.74 \times 10^{-3} \ll 1
\]

so we can approximate \(\mathrm{e}^{-2 Z r / a} \approx 1\). Thus,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &= \langle 100| H^{\prime}|100\rangle \\
& \approx \frac{4 Z^{4} e^{2}}{a^{3}} \int_{0}^{\rho}\left(r-\frac{3 r^{2}}{2 \rho}+\frac{r^{4}}{2 \rho^{3}}\right) \, \mathrm{d} r \\
&= \frac{4 Z^{4} e^{2}}{a^{3}}\left(\frac{\rho^{2}}{2}-\frac{\rho^{3}}{2 \rho}+\frac{\rho^{5}}{10 \rho^{3}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{2 Z^{4} e^{2} \rho^{2}}{5 a^{3}} = \frac{2}{5} \frac{e^{2}}{a} \cdot Z^{4}\left(\frac{\rho}{a}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(e^{2} / 2 a = 13.6 \, \mathrm{eV}\), then

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta E &= \frac{4}{5} \cdot 13.6 \, \mathrm{eV} \cdot Z^{4}\left(\frac{\rho}{a}\right)^{2} \\
& = \frac{4}{5} \times 13.6 \times (13)^{4} \times \left(\frac{10^{-13} 27^{1/3}}{5.3 \times 10^{-9}}\right)^{2} \, \mathrm{eV} \sim 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
\]
